abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Biallelic pathogenic variants in <jats:italic>ALDH1A3</jats:italic> are responsible for approximately 11% of recessively inherited cases of severe developmental eye anomalies. Some individuals can display variable neurodevelopmental features, but the relationship to the <jats:italic>ALDH1A3</jats:italic> variants remains unclear. Here, we describe seven unrelated families with biallelic pathogenic <jats:italic>ALDH1A3</jats:italic> variants: four compound heterozygous and three homozygous. All affected individuals had bilateral anophthalmia/microphthalmia (A/M), three with additional intellectual or developmental delay, one with autism and seizures and three with facial dysmorphic features. This study confirms that individuals with biallelic pathogenic <jats:italic>ALDH1A3</jats:italic> variants consistently manifest A/M, but additionally display neurodevelopmental features with significant intra- and interfamilial variability. Furthermore, we describe the first case with cataract and highlight the importance of screening <jats:italic>ALDH1A3</jats:italic> variants in nonconsanguineous families with A/M.</jats:p>

assertion.value: A Correction to this paper has been published:

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare no competing interests.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Families 1, 2, 4 and 7 are from research studies: UK ‘Genetics of Eye and Brain anomalies’ (Cambridge East Ethics Committee (04/Q0104/12)), Deciphering Developmental Disorders (DDD) Study (Cambridge South Research Ethics Committee (10/H0305/83), Republic of Ireland (GEN/284/12)) and Genetics of Congenital Ocular Disorders, Fundación Jimenez Díaz University Hospital (Ethics Research Committee FJD (PIC015-18)), respectively. Families 3, 5 and 6 were identified through diagnostic testing. Written informed consent for the scientific use and publication of the clinical data and images presented was obtained from all individuals in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki.
